text:
Cosmetic annoyance more than anything -- the worst part is that it once again
breaks the trust of patching. 
It reinforces (slightly erroneously I might add) that Microsoft doesn't do
quality control. In this case, they did, they knew this was going to happen. 
However I have a hard time understanding how badly this has been handled/lack of
communication/how it's being pushed out. It's only being pushed out on the
unmanaged side - so that's businesses using WU for business, Intune and a whole
bunch of consumers without any TPM chips that do not need this update. 
Before this impactful of an update, there should have been a lot more
communication on how to check on partition sizes. 
Furthermore per bleepingcomputer/Lawrence Adams research - build a brand new
Windows 10 from current ISOs and it builds a recovery partition that will barf
on this update.
https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/microsoft/windows-10-kb5034441-security-update-fails-with-0x80070643-errors/

"In a test by BleepingComputer this morning, a brand new install of Windows 10
using the latest ISO from Microsoft created a 522MB WinRE partition. However,
even this new install has a partition that is too small, causing the KB5034441
security update not to install and display a 0x80070643 error."
%40506bb204.com

metadata.subject: Re: [patchmanagement] You may hit a 0x80070643 - ERROR_INSTALL_FAILURE
